title: Everytime my browser closes, my Google cookies or cache gets corrupted (Linux)
content:
When I close my browser, my session with Google, Facebook and occasionally other sites is broken.

The current work around to fix it is: Settings -> Clear Cookies & Site Data -> type in google.com & youtube.com - remove those (see attached screengif)

So far I've tried:

Creating a new profile

I previously had a Firefox profile called "default" for many years. It served me well, after this happened everytime I restarted the browser, I created a new one called "Tim". The problem persists.

Clearing my cache

As mentioned - this works right up until I restart my browser.

An idea I have

Something weird is happening in the cache. If you see my second screencastgif - by clearing my google cookies and cache, apparently the size of the cache drops by 900mb. That's not plausible really, and it seems to be consistently happening every time I do this. In fact, the large number seems to be going up every time.

It makes me wonder if somehow, older cookies or cache are being reintroduced everytime somehow? Is that possible?

I'm somewhat technical but I haven't been doing weird stuff with my browser or tinkering much - I'm using Debian 11.5 with Firefox 102.3.0esr (64-bit) from Debian packages. I have a few extensions like ublock and firefox containers but far from overkill.

I'm happy to open sqllite files in DB_Browser_for_SQLite if it'll help. My cookies.sqlite seems? to be in good? condition?

Any sense of where to go hunting this down?
creator: tdobson

title: config / interface
content:
Does anyone make an effort to survey users before making changes? Some changes are just a bother but others are really imposing costs.

I see the disappearing HOME icon is a recurring problem. So, fine, I've restored the button. But my complicated half-dozen links have also disappeared and I have to reconstruct my HOME pages. Mine are complicated since they are a series of graphs (from Yahoo Finance), each with specific different parameters. It will really take me time to reconstruct this and I really resent that.

Similarly, where on earth did my plug-ins/extensions go? Again, they haven't just disappeared from the toolbar. Once I locate the icon and restore it, I find that they've disappeared from TOOLS > ADD-ONS AND THEMES. I have to go download them again? Why?

Naturally, all of this just happens to land on my plate on a very bad morning. Lesson learned: I'll make a bookmark folder to duplicate what the HOME button should bring up.

What is the point of all this?

Thanks for listening,

JeanneR Firefox 106.0.5 (64-bit) Win 8.1
creator: JeanneR

title: How to make Firefox accept a third-party cookie used for authentication by a Java web application?
content:
Hi,

I am a developer currently working on an open-source solution called GeoNetwork (https://github.com/geonetwork/core-geonetwork/). This application has a Java backend that uses a JSESSIONID cookie to track user sessions. One instance of the application can be accessed anonymously here: https://sextant.ifremer.fr/Donnees/Catalogue

The session cookie is set on the first request to the backend with the following parameters:

Domain: "sextant.ifremer.fr" expirationDate: "Session" HostOnly: true HttpOnly: true SameSite: "None" Secure: true

This application theoretically allows login in from a different origin. For example from https://www.milieumarinfrance.fr/Acces-aux-donnees/Catalogue, which under the hood points to the same backend. We noticed recently that when accessing the application from a different origin in Firefox, the network requests aimed at the "sextant.ifremer.fr" host *do not carry any existing session cookie*, thus rendering authenticated access impossible.

The existing session cookie is correctly used when I add an "allow" exception for the sextant.ifremer.fr origin in the cookies settings of Firefox (see attached screenshot in French). So I figure that it's Firefox that decides not to use any existing cookie when on this origin.

Is there any way to indicate to Firefox that this cookie is legitimate and that it is needed for essential functionalities, without relying on the user allowing the cookie explicitly?

Thanks a lot in advance!
creator: guyot.o

title: Hacked
content:
Hi all.

I have window 10, newish machine 2 yrs old, with MS Defender and Firewall installed and over weekend system was hacked by a search engine site (firefox) having a fake plumbing site. How could this happen ? Doesn´t Firefox have any protection against backdoor sites ? I am a cautious user not using any password manager nor any financial CC information stored. My trust has now been shattered. I write this to warn others. A long story cut short. The hacker got entry via the site into my notebook and ransomed me to pay 400 euros upfront to an XBox account to recover the machine. That never materialized. In the ensuing choas I attempted to turn the machine off, and the power button didn´t work. The hacker had gotton into the power plan and messed the program up that immoblized the power off function so he/she had more time to crib my files. On previous generation machines it was easier to take the battery pack out. Now not the case. The situation made worse that a communal Lan router was on another floor and impractical to pull the plug out. In my case I put the notebook in a microwave oven and slammed the door to screen it from the WLAN. It worked but it is ridiculous there is no other way. I blame MS for such useless protection Defender/Firewall programs and Mozilla must take the share of the blame too for allowing the clone on the browser. Even with remote connection disabled, if Hackers find it so easy to enter via the backdoor, then high time these companies upped the ante in making systems far more secure. Even with extra verification, it wouldn´t have worked. Now the next step is beyond home fiddling but have to take this to a IT specialist to root out any embedded 3rd party links. I welcome all comments.... one wonders all this stuff regarding privacy is really a rouse.
creator: richwalters

title: Firefox browser
content:
I've written in with this problem before, but got no emailed notification of replies, and don't know how to locate my previous post. The problem has happened again today. 

I was running Firefox with four Windows open (fewer than I used to before this problem started happening) and maybe a dozen or more tabs in each window. Suddenly, all four windows disappeared, and when I got Firefox restarted, only three of the windows came back. There was no trace at all of the one I had been using (probably looking at a YouTube video), and the "History" top menu item had the "Recently Closed Windows" tab greyed out. So my window was lost without any trace of ir or of the tabs it contained.   Much like this has happened before, except that on this occasion, the window I was actually using was the one that disappeared. No error messages appear.

I always have Chrome running at the same time, with two windows open. I've not experienced any such problem there.

I'm using a desktop PC with Windows 10. I also have a laptop, similarly configured which has not suffered the same problem. (No Chrome there.) I'm running a paid for version of Avast on both machines.

title: Firefox will not load sites that generate additional pages while other browsers can
content:
I'm having an issue where firefox is acting as if there's something blocking pages/content. I do not experience the issue on any other browser.

I first noticed it trying to log into one of my accounts. The login portal redirects the page to a success screen and then to the home page. With firefox after entering credentials it shows a blank page with a 500 error instead.More specifically I believe it has to do with an api for "duosecure" (checking for multi factor auth)

another example is trying to download chrome remote desktop - normally you click their download link and pauses the current page while it triggers a popup to chrome's page to download the extension. It does this in any other browser I try except firefox.

This is on a clean install of windows 10 and a clean install of firefox. I am on the latest version of firefox (tried 106 and updated to 107 via the beta options) I have: - cleared cookies and cache - restarted firefox - tried safe mode - tried with and without extensions/addons and have removed all - uninstalled firefox as well as deleted all appdata folders - tried unchecking hardware acceleration - setting dns to none and changing the dns server options - turned off any setting i could find regarding popups, blocking sites etc - manually turned off enhanced tracking - gone through windows firewall and security settings to turn off everything that i could find that was "on" - rebooted computer - rebooted router - used the "refresh" firefox to set it back to defaults - tried connecting to the internet via ethernet and wifi options - windows updates Note: logging into other things such as gmail or facebook are fine on firefox but they don't seem to trigger redirects to outside sites.
creator: sli4
